dlgLine.text: Hold it!
Take one more step and I'll cut you down where you stand.

dlgAnsw.text: Don't shoot!
Hold on - I didn't know there was anyone here. I'm lowering my weapon. Let's talk.
Don't take this the wrong way, but it stinks like death in here.
Famous last words, especially when someone points a gun at me.

dlgLine.text: Who are you and why the hell are you in my house?!

dlgAnsw.text: I'm from a shelter. We're looking for supplies and survivors.
Mister, it is putrid in here. What is that stench?
I saw the corpses on your lawn - I'm guessing you know how to use that gun.

dlgLine.text: That's none of your business!
Now what the hell are you doing in my house?!

dlgAnsw.text: I'm from a shelter. We're looking for supplies and survivors.
Don't you want to get out of here?
Why don't you give me that gun before you get hurt, old man.

dlgLine.text: I'm warning you - I may not have much, but if you think you're going to get it without a fight, you're about to make the worst mistake of your life.

dlgAnsw.text: You don't have much? That changes everything - let's talk.
What the fuck stinks in here?
I saw the corpses on your lawn - I'm guessing you know how to use that gun.
Why don't you give me that gun before you get hurt, old man.

dlgLine.text: You want it? Sure...

dlgAnsw.text: <The man aims the gun at your chest.>

dlgLine.text: You go ahead and lower yours. I'm not - this is my house. You got something to say, make it quick.

dlgAnsw.text: I'm from a shelter. We're looking for supplies and survivors.
I saw the corpses on your lawn - I'm guessing you know how to use that gun.
Are you okay? You look like you haven't slept in days.

dlgLine.text: Which shelter? Last I heard, they had been compromised.

dlgAnsw.text: It's in Splendid. There's just a few of us.
I'm not from a government shelter. We're just a group of survivors.

dlgLine.text: Uh-huh... Are you going to make me?

dlgAnsw.text: I could use another experienced shooter at our shelter.
Are you okay? You look like you haven't slept in days.
Why don't you give me that gun before you get hurt, old man.

dlgLine.text: Who can sleep anymore?

dlgAnsw.text: I can. We have a shelter. It's safe. Always looking for others to join.
I agree. Pretty impressive of you to hold out this long by yourself.

dlgLine.text: ...I can't.

dlgAnsw.text: - New Answ -

dlgLine.text: It doesn't matter... I can't leave. Unless...
Tell me - do they have a cure for it yet? The infection?

dlgAnsw.text: Cure? It's not an infection. Those people are dead.
I don't know. As far as I know, there isn't a government left to distribute it.
Are you bit?

dlgLine.text: I figured someone else survived.

dlgAnsw.text: - New Answ -

dlgLine.text: I could say the same. Maybe. I haven't decided if I'm going to shoot you yet.

dlgAnsw.text: I could use another experienced shooter at our shelter.
Whoa... I'm from a shelter in Splendid. I'm just a survivor like you.
If you want to keep on surviving, you better give me that gun.

dlgLine.text: No! No, that's not... that's not...

dlgAnsw.text: - New Answ -

dlgLine.text: I seriously doubt that. They prepared for nuclear winter, they're prepared for-

dlgAnsw.text: - New Answ -

dlgLine.text: No. And I already know about antibiotics from the radio. But...

dlgAnsw.text: - New Answ -

dlgLine.text: <A thumping noise emanates from behind the nearby barricaded door. The man looks at the door and back to you.>
You should go.

dlgAnsw.text: What was that?
Is that where the smell is coming from? You got one in there?
How long do you think you can hold out here?

dlgLine.text: None of your damn business!

dlgAnsw.text: - New Answ -

dlgLine.text: It doesn't matter.

dlgAnsw.text: - New Answ -

dlgLine.text: <Something begins pounding on the door.>
Please... Go.

dlgAnsw.text: Maybe I can help you.
Who's down there?
Just shoot it and get it over with.

dlgLine.text: Unless you've got a cure for that disease. No. There's nothing you can do.

dlgAnsw.text: There is no cure, I'm sorry. Whatever you think that is - it's not human anymore.
The only cure's a bullet in its head.
Maybe you didn't hear - that's not a disease. They're dead.

dlgLine.text: She's...
Look - it doesn't matter. Unless you know of a cure for this disease, I am not leaving.

dlgAnsw.text: She? I'm sorry. Whatever you think that is, it's not human anymore.
The only cure's a bullet in its head.
Maybe you didn't hear - that's not a disease. They're dead.

dlgLine.text: That is my wife down there! You...
Just get out...

dlgAnsw.text: I'm telling you the truth - there's no cure and she's not going to get better!
Sir, I need all the help I can get. You're alive - put the dead to rest and help me. Please.
I've lost people I love - I understand what you're going through. But that's the truth.
It's people like you that let this happen in the first place.

dlgLine.text: No... No you're wrong! My wife is not dead - do you hear me?!
<There is another series of thumps on the door.>
Just... just get out of here.

dlgAnsw.text: I'm telling you the truth - there's no cure and she's not going to get better!
Sir, I need all the help I can get. You're alive - put the dead to rest and help me. Please.
I've lost people I love - I understand what you're going through. But that's the truth.
It's people like you that let this happen in the first place.

dlgLine.text: No! Not me!

dlgAnsw.text: - New Answ -

dlgLine.text: I told her not to volunteer at that clinic... I begged her to stay here. She's was always trying to help people.
I was so angry at her when she came home bit.. So angry. She told me what was going to happen - said she had seen it. All she did was try to pull an infected person off a patient and...
Dammit, Becca... I tried so hard to keep her here...

dlgAnsw.text: I'm sorry. Most of us have similar stories.
That's not her. And you have to accept that and do the right thing.
You say she wanted to help people? Honor her memory and help us at the shelter.
You've killed other ones, right? You didn't figure it out?

dlgLine.text: I'm sure. But...

dlgAnsw.text: - New Answ -

dlgLine.text: I was married to her for forty years. Came back from a war for her. Raised three kids together. And I was ready to spend my golden years with her.
It's not that I don't know how to use a gun... I just haven't been ready to let her go.

dlgAnsw.text: I don't want sound cruel, but I could finish her for you.
Would she want you to die here?
If you're not ready to leave, I won't force you.
You used to be a soldier? Then you should know - the dead, they're the enemy.

dlgLine.text: She would want that. Probably. But...

dlgAnsw.text: - New Answ -

dlgLine.text: I was protecting my house. I don't know. Maybe, I knew. But...

dlgAnsw.text: - New Answ -

dlgLine.text: No!
No... I should be the one. I'll do it.

dlgAnsw.text: - New Answ -

dlgLine.text: No.
But... I can't leave her like that.

dlgAnsw.text: - New Answ -

dlgLine.text: Wait...
You say you're protecting others? I want to help.

dlgAnsw.text: - New Answ -

dlgLine.text: I haven't been a soldier in a long time. But I believe you.

dlgAnsw.text: - New Answ -

dlgLine.text: There's something I've got to do. Stay here... I'm going to do what needs to be done.
<The man walks out and in a few seconds you hear muffled speech followed by a gunshot.>

dlgAnsw.text: - New Answ -

dlgLine.text: ...We can go now.

dlgAnsw.text: Anything you else you need to get before you leave, mister, um...?
In case I need to get your attention, what's your name?

dlgLine.text: Bud. Gimme a sec to reload and then lead on.

dlgAnsw.text: I wish we could have met under better circumstances, Bud. We should go.
Follow me, Bud.
